newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish court says Walesa does not owe taxes.
newsitem.headline: Polish court says Walesa does not owe taxes.

text.p: An administrative court in the port of Gdansk ruled on Wednesday that former Polish president Lech Walesa would not have to pay any taxes on $1 million he received in 1989 for film rights.

Judge Boguslaw Szumacher said the Gdansk unit of the Supreme Administrative Court rejected a motion by the local tax office saying Walesa owed back taxes for money he received from Warner Brothers for the right to make a film about his life.
The court ruled that even if Walesa had been obliged to pay the taxes he should have done so by the end of 1994 and the obligation had now expired.
The issue of Walesa's taxes emerged during the 1995 presidential election in which he was narrowly defeated by his ex-communist challenger Aleksander Kwasniewski.
Walesa's aides said then that the fee was not liable to Polish tax and taxes had been paid in the United States.
Walesa told Reuters he felt only partially vindicated by the court's ruling. "I have won but who will give me back my reputation," he said.
